lines.text: Aren't you going to eat something, sir?
What'll I eat?
Well, sir, I...
Well, see, if you don't know, how should I know?

[holding up a diamond bracelet]
Er, I found this, sir.
You find the strangest things in a bachelor's apartment.
Do you suppose the lady lost anything else, sir?
Well, if she did, she didn't lose it here.
I'm tired of the parties and the women. The champagne as flat as the women.
What time does your train leave?
Two minutes--it can't be done.
Oh, please, please--please make him go faster!

[patting her hand]
Now, be reasonable--

[throwing off his hand]
I knew I should have taken a taxi.
I'd act the same way in a taxi.
Well, suppose it isn't any of the people in our set.
You don't think it would be an ordinary man? Like a grocery clerk or a vacuum cleaner salesman?
No, no--Agatha might commit a sin, but she'd never commit a faux pas.
I apologize.
For what?
For living.

Looks like our lucks changing, honey. They agency just phoned and told me to go to the ReTrac Investment Corporation at One Eleven Broadway. There's a stenographer's job open and it pays 35 dollars a week!
Now, don't start in saying no again. You're afraid to take a job here because you think that I might try to make love to you. Wouldn't you stand the same chance with any other employer?
Well, sure. A girl always runs that chance. But, here, I know what I was letting myself in for and it'd be my own fault.
After all, this is a matter of business and I am a businessman. I suppose that surprises you?
Well, yes, eh, it does. I thought of you as a - foolish, wealthy, Park Avenue playboy.
Well, thanks for that boring crack. I admire your frankness. I amuse myself as I see fit and I have no one to account. But, I do take my business seriously, even though it does bore me.
Did the agency mention any salary?
Yes, 35 dollars a week. But, what difference does that make?
It makes just 15 dollars difference. I'll start you off at 50.
There, you see. That, there, is just what I said. People don't pay 50 dollars a week for ordinary stenographers and you know it.

Will you stop trying to misunderstand me. This is not an ordinary stenographer's position. This is an executive secretary's position. Now, I feel all employees will have more dignity when the job pays more money.
It's no fun to work for a man you have to continually hold at arms length.
Well, believe me, anytime a secretary is her own boss there's something screwy in Denmark.
I wish I was in her shoes.
You're not the only one. We've all made a play for him, but, he doesn't know any of us are living.
Oh, I guess she's got what it takes or somethin'.
Oh, you're crazy. Listen, you must be dumb if you can't see through the whole thing. He never acted that way toward his old secretary.
And the air she puts on. You'd think she was some society dame out slummin'. She's been here three weeks and acts like she owns the joint.
I'll admit, when I first met you, I thought you were one of those girls that pretends to be innocent just to - lead a man on. It's funny, now that we know each other better, doesn't it?
I wonder what you really think of me now?
I think you're an extremely intelligent girl. There's nothing smug about you. You understand a man's point of view.
You know, you're the first woman I've ever dared to be frank with. You know what I am, the way I live. Perhaps you're a bit shocked?
Oh, no, I'm not a bit shocked, Mr. Carter. I believe in everybody doing exactly as they please.
So do I. We understand each other perfectly.
You know, you don't know what a relief it is not to lie and flatter and get something that's a fake, when you do get it.
Well, you're a peculiar man. Why do you tell me all these things about yourself?
Why not! If I were trying to make you fall in love with me, I wouldn't bare myself this way. We never can mean anything to each other, so, why not?
Darling, from now on I'm spending as much time as I please with you. Aren't you pleased?
Now, Agatha, be sensible. Herb's a friend of mine. If you don't get out of here, I'm going to carry you out bodily.
Oh, Wayne! Be sweet to me! You're all I've got in the world!
I thought I could trust Agatha because she is as cold as marble. But, she's even cold with me.
Well, I guess I've taken enough of your time. You'll send that detective to see me?
Leave it to me, Herb, and I'll fix the whole thing up. In the meantime, I'll have a talk with Agatha and try to straighten her out.
You've bucked me up immensely, Wayne, old man.
Not at all. Not at all. You've made me feel this thing means as much to me as it does to you.
Is there any more dictation, Mr. Carter?
I believe that girl is a prude, after all.
Will you put on your clothes and get out of here this minute!
I never heard a girl say no, so much.
